Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation2: It's time for the routine quarterly filing of internal financial documents.
Story: I stared at the calendar, my heart tugged in two directions. The family gathering was circled in bright red, a promise I’d made to my daughter and grandkids weeks ago. They expected me to be there, to laugh, to share stories, to be the grandparent who never missed a moment. But as I glanced at the stack of financial documents on my desk, a different kind of responsibility pressed on me. The quarterly filing deadline loomed, and as the company’s accountant, I knew the records had to be flawless—no errors, no delays. My boss trusted me to keep everything in order, and any slip-up could mean trouble for the whole team. I could almost hear my granddaughter’s voice asking if I’d play cards with her, while at the same time, I imagined the anxious emails from my supervisor if the reports weren’t submitted on time. My chest tightened as I weighed the expectations—family warmth on one side, professional duty on the other. I sat there, torn, knowing I couldn’t give both my best at the same time.
